awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Integrating megafauna community reassembly with ecosystem carbon cycling
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Climate change (mediated by accelerated carbon emissions) and wildlife community reassembly (mediated by unprecedented rates of species introduction and loss) are environmental calling cards of our modern era. However, the connection between changes to wildlife communities and changes in the carbon cycle is rarely drawn, despite growing recognition that wildlife may control carbon exchange between ecosystems and the atmosphere. This project will demonstrate how management of wildlife can mediate uptake and storage of carbon in a boreal forest ecosystem, potentially offering a nature-based climate solution, and more accurately account for sources and fates of carbon in the system’s carbon budget.  The Fellow will train the next generation of scientists (high school, undergraduate and graduate) from diverse backgrounds by integrating wildlife conservation with ecosystem science using field and laboratory methods, data science, and carbon modeling. 

This project quantifies impacts of moose populations on carbon cycling in the boreal forest of Newfoundland, Canada. Boreal forests are a sink for atmospheric carbon, but Newfoundland’s forest’s capacity as a carbon sink may be threatened by rising populations of introduced moose and their foraging impacts on forest biomass and soil biogeochemistry. The study will systematically examine how variation in moose population abundances links to changes to forest carbon storage and emissions across a landscape-scale moose density gradient. The Fellow will quantify carbon stored aboveground in tree biomass, carbon stored in soil, and the soil carbon emissions in relation to local moose abundance and local biophysical features of the landscape. These three aspects of carbon cycling will be measured with drone imagery, soil sampling and carbon analyses in the laboratory, and custom carbon-emissions detecting sensors, respectively. The data will holistically describe moose impacts on carbon storage and emissions. These insights will be used to develop a model relating moose density and landscape features to carbon cycling across Newfoundland to provide a spatial decision-support tool  for landscape management to enhance ecosystem carbon uptake and storage. The Fellow will receive training in soil and climate science, landscape ecology, and data science as well as providing outreach to students on these topics through multiple online and in-person venues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes: events and actions

Dr. Elizabeth Forbes has completed her NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, which took place between October 2021-October 2023 and was hosted in the lab of Dr. Oswald Schmitz at the Yale School of the Environment. Dr. Forbes conducted two seasons of field research in Newfoundland; lab analyses of samples collected during these field seasons; redeveloped the novel, autonomous soil carbon dioxide emissions sensor featured in her PRFB project proposal along with Yale University engineers, including adding remote sensing and data transmission capabilities; field-tested the redesigned “fluxbot” in the field in 2023 in both Newfoundland and at Harvard Forest’s long term soil carbon flux monitoring sites; collaborated with field researchers at Parks Canada and in Memorial University’s biology department; traveled to Memorial University to give a seminar on her work; presented the results of her research at the 2023 annual meetings of the Ecological Society of America and the American Geophysical Union; co-organized three organized oral sessions at the 2023 ESA that focused on the overarching principles that inspired her PRFB project; served as the instructor of record for Yale School of the Environment’s “Foundations in Ecology” course in fall 2023; and mentored graduate and undergraduate students at Yale and Memorial universities spanning the natural and engineering sciences.

 

Outcomes: broader impacts

            During the fellowship, Dr. Forbes established solid working relationships with colleagues at Memorial University beyond co-mentor Dr. Leroux. In addition to being advised by Dr. Leroux, Dr. Forbes developed working relationships with Dr. Yolanda Wiersma and masters and PhD students in both Leroux and Wiersma labs (including conducting fieldwork together and sharing collaborative data). These connections were essential to developing Dr. Forbes’ relationship with Parks Canada, with whom she worked extensively not only to gain access to Gros Morne and Terra Nova national parks but also for optimal site selection, site access, scientific results sharing, and brainstorming practical applications of the research. In particular, Parks Canada ecologist Dr. Darroch Whitaker’s expertise and guidance proved essential to the progress of the project and Dr. Forbes looks forward to working with Dr. Whitaker on recommendations for Parks Canada’s existing moose management protocols using outcomes from her research.

            Dr. Forbes utilized her time as a PRFB fellow to actively mentor students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. At Memorial University, she acted as a mentor to four master’s level researchers during fieldwork, and to one undergraduate researcher who worked as a field technician with Dr. Forbes in 2023. At Yale University, she acted as a mentor to two PhD researchers, five master’s level researchers while conducting labwork on samples collected in Newfoundland, as well as on data science exploring the results of the lab and fieldwork. She served as primary mentor and supervisor to one undergraduate researcher, who continues to work with Dr. Forbes. Lastly, Dr. Forbes conducted sixteen “Skype a Scientist” sessions during her tenure, with classrooms as young as first grade and as old as twelfth.

 

Outcomes: intellectual merit and findings

            Dr. Forbes conducted two “field seasons” during her tenture as a PRFB fellow: in 2022 and 2023. In both seasons, she collected multiple datasets across two national parks: Gros Morne and Terra Nova national parks. Specifically, she collected data on soil carbon and nitrogen content, soil bulk density, soil carbon dioxide emissions rates, vegetation community composition at the ground to the canopy levels, moose abundance, and moose activity (e.g. browsing). To explore the effects of forest canopy disturbance and moose density on these variables, she collected these data at an a priori identified range of sites: mature forest, canopy gaps formed by firewood harvesting, canopy gaps formed by historical insect outbreak, canopy gaps formed by historical fire, and moose-free fenced exclosure plots (set up by Parks Canada more than 20 years ago).

She found that soil carbon dioxide emissions rates in the mature forest adjacent to canopy gaps responds differently to increasing moose density, with rates increasing with increasing moose density in mature stands adjacent to firewood harvesting gaps. Contrary to her initial hypothesis, Dr. Forbes found that on average, soil carbon dioxide emissions rates (relativized to time of day measured) are higher in mature forest stands compared to gaps in the canopy, and potentially correlated with the depth of the organic layer (which is higher in the mature stands than in the gaps). However, she found that emissions rates tend to be much more variable in canopy gaps, no matter their genesis, compared to in mature stands. Dr. Forbes also found that the percent of soil carbon and nitrogen tends to increase with increasing moose density, regardless of location (e.g. mature stand or canopy gap).
